fields.name: Ardipithecus
fields.remarks: Ardipithecus ramidus is first described as Australopitheucus ramidus sp. nov. in White, Suwa Aswfaw, 1994, then a corrigum is published in Nature as White, Suwa Asfaw 1995. This one page article describes the genus Ardipithecus.
fields.label: Ardipithecus

fields.name: Homo habilis
fields.remarks: The species Homo habilis was first described by Leakey et al. (1964) to accommodate new fossils discovered in 1960 from Olduvai Gorge, locality FLKNN 1 that were clearly distinct from the Zinjanthropus (now Australopithecus or Paranthropus) boisei material discovered in 1959. The type specimen of Homo habilis, Olduvai Hominid 7 (OH 7) was united with OH 4, OH 6, OH 8 and OH 13 as paratypes to erect the new species. The original diagnostic description highlights the presence of a strong, precision grip in Homo habilis, ostensibly part of an adaptation for tool use. The authors note an increased average cranial capacity in Homo habilis relative to Australopithecus (ca 600 vs 400 cc), but smaller than what is seen in Homo erectus (ca 800 cc). The skull of Homo habilis has reduced temporal lines that never converge in the midline and thus never form the sagittal crest seen in Australopithecus and the greatest breath of the skull is found between The molars are noted to be smaller than those of Australopithecus, especially in the bucco-lingual dimension. Throughout the 1960’s - 1990’s Homo habilis (sensu lato) became a widely defined taxon that included a very large number of specimens from Olduvai Gorge and Koobi Fora in Kenya. The taxon was revised by Wood (1992) and split into Homo habilis (sensu strictu) and Homo rudolfensis.
fields.label: Homo habilis

fields.name: Ardipithecus kadabba
fields.remarks: Specimens from Middle Awash locality ALA-VP-2 including the holotype right mandible and associated teeth ALA-VP-2/10 were first attributed the subspecies Ardipithecus ramidus kadabba Haile-Selassie, 2001, then later elevated to species status as Ardipithecus kadabba Haile-Selassie, 2004.
fields.label: Ardipithecus kadabba

fields.name: Australopithecus afarensis
fields.remarks:
Johanson, White and Coppens (1978) coined the name Au. afarensis with LH 4 as the type and Garusi 1 as a paratype. Garusi 1 itself is a type specimen described by Weinert (1950) as Meganthrpus africanus. Johanson, White and Coppens (1978) recognized Garusi 1 and the rest of the hypodigm as fitting within the genus Australopithecus, however transfering the name Meganthropus africanus to the genus Australalopithecus creates a homonym with Australpoithecus africans Dart, 1925, which prompted Johanson, White and Coppens (1978) to coin the new name Australopithecus afarensis Johanson, White and Coppens 1978. However, while their paper was in press it was preempted by a scientific news announcement published by Hinrichsen (1978) in which the author announced the name Australopithecus afarensis and attributed it to Johanson alone. Day et al. (1980) have argued that Henrichsen (1978) meets the criteria for a valid nomenclatural act and thus the formal name for this taxon should be Australpithecus afarensis Johanson, 1978 (in Henrichsen, 1978). The sequence of events is also summarized in Kimbel and Delzene (2009).

Heinrichs (1978) did not name a holotype, thus the subsequent holotype designation by Johanson et al. 1978 is technically a lectotype designation (a lectotype denotes a type specimen designated subsequent to the publication of the name). 

Groves (1996) formally requuested that the ICZN supress the name Meganthropus africanus and grant priority to Australopithecus afarensis. This appeal was made in case number 2998, with comments from White et al. (1998) and approved by ICZN in 1999 as opinion number 1941.

Strait et al. (1997) and Strait and Grine (2004) advance a cladistic classification for the australopiths and place Australopithecus afarensis into its own genus, Praeanthrous Senyürek, 1955. However this does not solve the problem of paraphyly for Au. anamensis, Au. garhi and other australopith taxa.
fields.label: Australopithecus afarensis

fields.name: Homo sapiens
fields.remarks: The species Homo sapiens was described by Linnaeus in the 10 edition of Systema Naturae (1758) but no holotype was designated as part of the original description, as was customary at the time. The question of holotype is addressed in a FAQ on the ICZN website by David Notton and Chris Stringer, where they indicated Carl Linnaeus himself is the lectotype as designated by William Stearn in 1959. They also refute the designation of Edward Cope. Cope is unavailable as a lectotype because he was not alive at the in 1758 and could therefore not be considered among the specimens considered by Linnaeus. Spamer (1999) provides a full description of the history and context of the debate. The fossil record of Homo sapiens now extends to at least 300 ka (Hublen et al. 2017) and includes several morphological subspecies such as Homo sapiens idaltu from Herto, Ethiopia (White et al. 2003).
fields.label: Homo sapiens

fields.name: Homo rudolfensis
fields.remarks: Richard Leakey and his team are the first to describe KNM-ER 1470 in 1973, though they do not create the new taxon (Leakey, 1973). Homo rudolfensis, then declared as a species by V.P. Alekseev in 1986 as Pithecanthropus rudolfensis, is a highly disputed hominin (V.P. Alekseev, 1986). Because of its status as a debated species H. rudolfensis is often referred to as a subspecies of Homo habilis though arguments have been made that it may also be a member of the Australopithecus genus. This discourse comes from the australopithecine features H. rudolfensis retained in contrast with the early Homo characteristics presented in its body plan (McHenry and Coffing, 2000). Within studies and articles the type specimen KNM-ER 1470 is most commonly used to refer to H. rudolfensis as few fossils have been concretely determined to be of the species. Much that is written about H. rudolfensis revolves around discourse on if the species exists or, if it does, then which genus it should be placed in (Collard M. and Wood B., 2001).
fields.label: Homo rudolfensis

fields.name: Kenyanthropus platyops
fields.remarks: Kenyanthropus platyops was discovered on the western shore of Lake Turkana, Kenya by a member of Meave Leakey’s research team, Justus Erus in 1999 (Gee, 2001). The species is known for its distinguished human-like facial features such as a flat face, smaller teeth, and smaller brain (Lieberman, 2001). It was found that K. platyops shared similar features with Australopithecines (afarensis and deyiremeda) these similarities would include the position of the zygomatic process, small first and second molars, and three upper molars with three roots (Spoor et al., 2016). Kenyanthropus platyops also shared the same shape of the dental arcade, maxillary morphology, and molar size as Australopithecus deyiremeda (Haile-Selassie, 2015). Middle Pliocene diversity is attributed to the discovery of K. platyops in Lake Turkana (Haile-Selassie, 2015, Leakey, 2001). There appeared to be slight controversy of whether K. platyops should be its own species or if it should be assigned to Homo rudolfensis. However, based on the combination of primitive and advanced cranial features, it is regarded as its own genus (Leakey, 2001 & Gee, 2001).
fields.label: Kenyanthropus platyops

fields.name: Paranthropus aethiopicus
fields.remarks: Arambourg and Coppens originally named OMO 18 as the type specimens for Paraustralopithecus aethiopicus. Groves 1999 discusses some of the challenges and problems surrounding the designation of the name 'aethiopicus'. The name Paranthropus aethiopicus is available, but Australopithecus aethiopicus is not available and creates a hominym referring both to fossils from Laetoli and from Omo.
fields.label: Paranthropus aethiopicus

fields.name: Australopithecus garhi
fields.remarks: In the middle of the Awash Valley of Ethiopia, a research team led by Berhane Asfaw and Tim White in 1996, discovered a new species of Australopithecus and named it Australopithecus garhi that is thought to live around 2.5 million years ago in the Early Pleistocene era. This first discovery included a proximal femur and portions of the mandible, and later cranial fragments and a mandible were found (Asfaw, 1999). This species has large, durable molars, but its other dental traits like the ratio of canine to molars are similar to those found in the early Homo specimens, which raises the question if A. garhi is ancestral to Homo (Culotta, 1999). A. garhi is thought to be a turning point species between Australopithecus and Homo, but this discussion is still going on today. Additionally, A. garhi is known to be the first species to have evidence of stone tool, mainly Oldowan tools, used for hunting fauna that is indicated by the findings of stone tools and bones with tool-like cuts in the same time period that A. garhi is thought to exist in (Toth, 2006).
fields.label: Australopithecus garhi

fields.name: Zinjanthropus boisei
fields.remarks: Holotype OH 5 originally described in 1959 and named Zinjanthropus boisei. Later included in the Paranthropus hypodym, or if one does not accept unique validity of Paranthropus then both are included under Australopithecus.
fields.label: Paranthropus boisei

fields.name: Australopithecus africanus
fields.remarks:
First named by Raymond Dart in 1925 Nature publication. However, Groves 1999 refers to Australopithecus africanus Dart 1924. Is there some earlier publication in 1924 or is this a mistake in the date? The first paragraph of Dart's 1925 article in nature indicates the Taung skull was discovered "Late in 1924" so a 1925 publication and date for the name seems apprpriate. The Nature article is clearly dated to February 1925. 

Zoobank lists Australopithecus africanus Dart 1925.
fields.label: Australopithecus africanus

fields.name: Praeanthropus
fields.remarks: The genus Praeanthropus was originally coined by Hennig (1948), but that name is invalid under the ICZN because Hennig (1948) did not provide a specific name. Senyurek (1955) argued that the Garusi I maxilla, attributed to Meganthropus africanus by Weinert (1950) belonged in a new genus and resurrected Hennig's Praeanthropus, now Praeanthropus Senyürek, 1955. Stait et al. (1997) and Strait and Grine (2004) have argued to move Australopithecus afarensis to Praeantthropus in order to reduce the paraphyly of taxa in Australopithecus. However, a full implementation of this solutioin also requires minting new generic names for Au. anamensis, Au. garhi and other australopits, except Au. africanus, which is the type species in the genus.
fields.label: Praeanthropus

fields.name: Ardipithecus ramidus
fields.remarks: Originally described as Australopithecus ramidus White, Suwa & Asfaw 1994, then updated to Ardipithecus ramidus in one page corrigum in White, Suwa & Asfaw 1995.
fields.label: Ardipithecus ramidus

fields.name: Orrorin tugenensis
fields.remarks:
Holotype BAR 1000'00

Orrorin tugenensis, BAR 1000’00, was discovered in Tugen Hills (Lukeino Formation, Baringo District), Kenya in 2001 by Brigitte Senut and their team (Senut et al. 2001). With its name meaning ‘Original Man’, O. tugenensis is approximately 6 million years old dating back to the Late Miocene (Sawada et al., 2002). A total of 13 fossils, skeletal remains from five individuals discovered of Orrorin tugenensis were found in four different localities within the Lukeino Formation: Cheboit, Kapsomin, Kapcheberek, and Aragai (Senut et al., 2001). O. tugenensis has shed light on the emergence of bipedalism based on its femora (Pickford et al., 2002; Galik et al. 2004). BAR 1002’00, the left femur is predominantly complete containing the femoral shaft, neck, and head. Based on the anterior twist of the femoral neck, lesser trochanter projecting medially, and the size of the femoral head, it was concluded that O. tugenensis must have been bipedal as opposed to other australopithecines (Pickford et al, 2002). Pickford et al. also significantly concluded that from the evidence provided by the fossil remains Orrorin is most closely related to modern humans than australopithecines. This in turn went to mean that Orrorin is more closely related to the genus Homo than it is to the genus Paranthropus and Australopithecus.
fields.label: Orrorin tugenensis

fields.name: Plesianthropus
fields.remarks: In 1936 Broom attributed fossils from Sterkfontein to Australopithecus transvalensis Broom 1936. In 1938 erected a new genus for this species, Plesianthropus transvalensis Broom 1938.
fields.label: Plesianthropus

fields.name: Australopithecus transvaalensis
fields.remarks: Broom 1936 erects the name Au. transvaalensis for first fossils discovered at Sterkfontein. Broom 1938 proposes Sterkfontein fossils belong in new genus and proposes Plesianthropus transvaalensis. In 1947 STS 5 is discovered and referred to Plesianthropus transvaalensis. Current concensus taxonomy treates Plesianthorpus transvaalensis as a junior synonym of Australopithecus africanus.
fields.label: Australopithecus transvaalensis

fields.name: Meganthropus africanus
fields.remarks: Weinert used Meganthropus africanus for Garusi I. Later Johanson, White & Coppens 1978 erected Australopithecus afarensis considering Weinert 1950 invalid, but Weinert 1950 was available. ICZN Opinion 1941 formally supresses Meganthropus africanus to avoid confusion with Au. africanus.
fields.label: Meganthropus africanus

fields.name: Paranthropus crassidens
fields.remarks: Broom 1949 is first use of the name Paranthrpus crassidens. Broom and Robinson later use the name Paranthropus crassidens Broom and Robinson 1949. Its not exactly clear which is valid. The first publication does use the name and references a specimen.

fields.name: Homo antecessor
fields.remarks: The type specimen of Homo antecessor, ATD 6-5, was first discovered in 1995 at Gran Dolina, Sierra de Atapuerca, Burgos, Spain by Eudald Carbonell and his team (Carbonell et al., 1995). The species was officially declared following further examination of the finds in 1997 as the last common ancestor shared between modern humans and Homo neanderthalensis (de Castro et al,. 1997). H. antecessor displayed a variety of features common in other species that together make up a unique species. The specimens found at Gran Dolina in Stratum TD6 are dated to 780,000 years ago, though a molar found at Sima del Elefante has been dated to 1.2 million years ago (Martinón-Torres et al., 2011). Evidence of cannibal practices has been attributed to H. antecessor based on the markings found on the remains at Atapuerca TD6 (Fernández-Jalvo et al., 1999).
fields.label: Homo antecessor
fields.verbatim_name: Homo antecessor Bermúdez de Castro et al., 1997

fields.name: Homo floresiensis
fields.remarks: Homo floresiensis was discovered on the island of Flores in Indonesia in a cave site called Liang Bua by an Indonesian-Australian team led by Peter Brown and Mike Morwood in 2004 (Brown et al, 2004). Homo floresiensis is dated to exist around 60-100 KYA; however, what is unique about this species is that they were extremely small with a dwarfed-liked stature and a brain size of around 400 cc (Hershkovitz, 2007). This small stature has given this species the nickname “The Hobbit” (Meijer, 2010). Flores, Indonesia was surrounded by water at the time that Homo floresiensis was thought to have existed, which gives insight to how this species could have become the dwarfed version of other Homo species that existed at the same time (O’Connor et al, 2017). Multiple theories rose to combat this unique feature and one particular theory is Insular Dwarfism, which occurs when species are isolated in an area for an extended period of time (Van Der Geer et al, 2018). Although this species was separated from the mainland, the stone tools that are found with H. floresiensis are more advanced than the Oldowan tools found with H. erectus, which included tools such as blades and flaked tools. For a while, H. floresiensis was only found at Liang Bua, but recent discoveries of more tiny hominins in Mata Menge, Flores in 2014 might shed some more light on this hobbit species (Van den Bergh et al., 2016).
fields.label: Homo floresiensis

fields.name: Australopithecus anamensis
fields.remarks: The name 'anem' means lake in the Turkana language. Widely regarded as direct ancestor to Australopithecus afarensis. The holotype is KNM-KP 29281. Most of the hypodigm derives from Kanapoi localities situated about 36 deg, 04' E and 2 deg 19' N between the Kalabata and Kakurio rivers in Turkana District, northern Kenya.
fields.label: Australopithecus anamensis

fields.name: Australopithecus bahrelghazali
fields.remarks: Bahr el Ghazal is classical arabic for River of the Gazelles. Holotype specimen is KT 12/H1, mandible with R i2-p4 and Lc-p4 (Note origianl anatomical description in 1995 Nature paper Fig 2 is incorrect and ommits left p4). The locality is variably referred to as either KT 12 or KT12 (with and without a space). Paratype KT 12/H2 is an upper right P3.

fields.name: Homo ergaster
fields.remarks: Holotype KNM ER-992
fields.label: Homo ergaster

fields.name: Homo luzonensis
fields.remarks:
Holotype is CCH6-a to CCH6-e

Paratypes: CCh1, CCH2, CCH5, CCH3, CCH4, CCH8, CCH9
fields.label: Homo luzonensis

fields.name: Australopithecus sediba
fields.remarks: In the original description Berger et al. (2010) has a section called "Holotype and paratype" in which they list MH1 and MH2 but never state which is the holotype. MH1 is a juvenile while MH2 is an adult. Specimen MH1 has separate catalog numbers for each element, e.g. UW88-1 for the right clavical, which was the first specimen to be discoverd.

fields.name: Homo heidelbergensis
fields.remarks: Schoetensack (1908) is a monograph description of the Maur 1 mandible. Although the title and text reference Homo heidelbergensis, there is not portion of the text that explicitly erects the new species, yet it still meets the ICZN criteria and is considered a valid nomenclatural act.

fields.name: Paraustralopithecus
fields.remarks: Arambourg and Coppens (1968) attributed the mandible Omo 18-1967-18 to a new genus and species, Paraustralopithecus aethiopicus. For many years it was considered a junior synonym of Paranthropus boisei, but the discovery of the black skull and subsequent revisions led to the re-accptance of this taxon though under the genus Paranthropus as Paranthropus aethiopicus.

fields.name: Homo leakeyi
fields.remarks: Clarke (1990) argues that African material attributed to Homo erectus should be placed in a distinct species and nominated Homo leakeyi.
